article_title: Feds penalize Nix, UHS for patient infections, wounds
article_text:
Feds penalize Nix, UHS for patient infections, wounds

Two San Antonio hospitals are being penalized this fiscal year for infections and injuries that patients suffered while in their care, according to data released by Medicare.

article_metadata.description: The evaluation also assessed central-line bloodstream infections and catheter-associated urinary tract infections reported in 2012 and 2013, according to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.  The hospital earned a 9 in the patient safety category, which evaluated incidents such as bedsores, blood clots, surgical wound ruptures, postoperative sepsis and accidental punctures or lacerations.  “Nix Health is committed to delivering safe, high-quality care to every patient,” Dr. Dina Goytia-Leos, president of Nix’s medical staff, said in a prepared statement.  The tax-supported hospital earned the worst possible score in the patient safety category and was given an only slightly better score of 8 for catheter-related urinary tract infections.  [...] it received a midlevel score of 6 for bloodstream infections caused by catheters placed in large veins to medicate or take blood from patients.  Academic medical centers were hit particularly hard by the evaluation, with half of them nationally being penalized, Kaiser reported.  Because the data used in the calculations dates back to 2011, University Hospital said the numbers do not reflect its work to improve safety and to reduce the risk of such incidents.  University recently took part in a national research study to reduce the risk of patient infections in the intensive care unit.  “The goal is to achieve a zero rate of infections, and the scores indicate we continue to trend in the right direction,” said Dr. David Siegel, Baptist’s chief medical officer.  “We continue to review our results and have seen a marked improvement in patient outcomes in 2014,” Dr. James Martin, Christus Santa Rosa's chief medical officer, said in a prepared statement Monday.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O'Hare, Staff Writer
